prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The first spectral set-up covering 275.2-278.95 GHz, and 287.2-290.95 GHz. Prominent lines include the CH3CN 15-14 ladder, the CH3OH 5-4 ladder, DCO+ and DCN 3-2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The point of this proposal is to obtain a spectral line survey, and the highest spectral resolution available for the largest band width is therefore requested. A substantially lower resolution than 1km/s will decrease the sensitivity of the observations since it will not allow us to apply Keplerian filters when extracing lines. We opted to manually setting up the survey as 6 spectroscopic science goals since the spectral scan mode results in ~230% overheads due to the calibration scheme where band bass calibration is acquired for the entire scan (up to 5 pass band calibrations are thus needed) and an inefficient correlator set-up with substantial spectral overlaps for our desired spectral resolution.

We need the high data rate to cover the maximum amound of spectral band width (~7.5 GHz) with a resolution of 1 km/s in all settings. The wide band width is essential to efficiently carry out a line survey and as note above a lower spectral resolution than 1 km/s will be detrimental to the retrival of faint lines using kinematics-based (Keplerian) matched filters.

The chosen angular resolution corresponds to the largest scales at which N-bearing organics are detected in the disks of MWC 480 and LkCa 15. A higher resolution may therefore decrease the sensitivity for the kind of species we hope to discover with this proposal. A 1" resolution, rather than a lower one, is desirable since it will enable us to resolve chemical structures for the stronger lines detected in this survey. The disks have ~2" radi and a 1" beam is therefore sufficient to distinguish between inner and outer disk chemistry.

The requested sensitivity of 3 mJy per spectral resolution element is based on the goal to detect 15 mJy (peak flux) lines from CH3CN and similarly complex molecules at the 5sigma level across at least 3 channels for each line (typical line widths are 4-6 km/s). This sensitivity corresponds to column density sensitiviies of ~1e12 cm-2 for a large variety of organics moecules, which provides useful tests to astrochemical disk models. The maxmum bandwidth is used since this is a line survey and the line widths exceed the spectral resolution in widest bands by ~3x.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The second spectral set-up covering 278.95-282.70 GHz, and 290.95-294.70 GHz. Prominent lines include N2H+ 3-2, a H2CO 4-3 line, and CS 3-2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The third spectral set-up covering 283.45-287.20 GHz, and 295.45-298.20 GHz. Prominent lines include several c-C3H2 lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The fourth spectral set-up covering 298.30-302.05 GHz, and 310.3-314.05 GHz. Prominent lines include several c-C3H2 lines, and a prominent H2CO line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The fifth spectral set-up covering 302.5-305.80 GHz, and 314.05-317.80 GHz. Prominent lines include SiO 7-6, several SO lines, DNC and c-C3H2 lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sp. set. #6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The sixth spectral set-up covering 305.8-309.55 GHz, and 317.80-321.55 GHz. Prominent lines include c-C3H2 lines, N2D+ 4-3, and strong methanol lines.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The point of this proposal is to obtain a spectral line survey, and the highest spectral resolution available for the largest band width is therefore requested. A substantially lower resolution than 1km/s will decrease the sensitivity of the observations since it will not allow us to apply Keplerian filters when extracing lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The volatile composition of protoplanetary disks regulates the outcomes of planet formation, including planet bulk properties and chemical habitability. Molecules also provide the only probes of disk kinematics, gas masses, snowlines and other defining disk characteristics. To guide future studies of disks we, as a community, need to know what molecules are present at detectable abundances in disks. We therefore propose to carry out a band 7 spectral line survey toward two young disks around T Tauri star LkCa 15 and Herbig Ae star MWC 480 with an O- and N-rich chemistry respectively. The targeted 45 GHz wide window covers several common disk probes, but the real motivation for the survey is its legacy value as the first unbiased view of disk volatile compositions. To maximize its utility to the disk community we waive all proprietary time and commit to deliver the first fully reduced data products within a month of data arrival. These data will provide the first key steps towards characterizing the organic content of protoplanetary disks across the mass and luminosity regime, directing future ALMA observations beyond our current biased view.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
